content.description:
Start with your feet stemming on the two side walls and make your way up, using both the side and back walls as needed. Top out on your left. For maximum fun, move as dynamically as possible, comp bouldering style.



This one's  a little farther down the trail, above trail level. It's about as far left as you can go before the cliff face really starts to mellow out.

Clean fall.

You'll have to make your way around the tree before you can go up. This one's slightly overhanging with some good moves.

Start with a foot on the edge just above the fork of the birch tree. Left hand on a jug beside the left trunk of the tree, and right hand on a high jug to the outside of the right trunk. 



On the left side of the big main wall, at trail level. Look for the tree.

Clean enough fall, although there are a few rocks at the edge of the landing zone that you may want to cover with extra pads.

Start with right foot in large pocket just above ground level. Left and right hands compressing on side pulls. Essentially follow the line of the crack, using good face holds.



On the far right side of the crag, at ground level, close to the main Frame Lake trail.

Clean fall.

Start with your left hand on the good opening on the rail, right hand on a deep crimper, left foot on large edge and right foot on smaller edge closer to ground level. Trend slightly left as you go up.



Near the left end of the slab with the Santa, Baby! crack, before the face gets too short to climb and the talus starts.

Clean fall.

Go up the very pinchable arete, staying to the left and avoiding the large edges and ledge to your right.

Sit start, with both hands on a large block and both feet on a good edge just above the ground.



The right side of the Santa, Baby! crack, on the left side of the field, on the lower tier (at trail level).

Clean landing zone.

A body-height vertical section that turns into a low-angle dihedral. To start, there's a slopey gaston for your left hand, a nice edge for your right hand, and a good edge for your right foot.



On the upper level of the crag, just to the left of the lower-level main wall.


Between the angle of the wall and the imperfect landing zone, a fall would be mildly concerning but probably not life-threatening.

Start with both hands on the large edge, and feet on anything they'll grip to (there are some dime edges to use). Dyno up to the big jug that's used as a stating hold for Bowline. From there, continue on the same line as you would for Bowline.

V5 is totally a guess. It's a mighty big dyno to start, that a lot of people won't be able to reach. After that, the moves mellow out significantly.



Essentially the same line as Bowline, but with a totally different start.

Clean enough fall, although there are a few rocks at the edge of the landing zone that you may want to cover with extra pads.

A fun traverse problem using a variety of hold types--rounded ledges, jugs, pockets, side pulls, crimps and jams. The wall is slightly overhanging the whole way, and the feet are mostly thin, with a couple of good edges to rest on.

Start with both hands on the large edge near the far right of the wall, facing to your right, left foot pressing against a vertical edge about a foot and a half above the ground, and right foot floating.

Eleven feet tall at its highest point, plus 13 feet of traversing before going up.

*Mild beta spoilers* Heel hook the big edge near the tree using your right foot. Walk your hands along the big ledge, mostly using small edges for your feet. You can make use of side pulls and a nice edge for your foot to transition to the small ledge section about halfway through the problem. Once past the halfway point, there are jugs and big crimps (and a huge edge for your feet) to make your way up the taller section. There's a crack near the top you can use for a finger jam.

A note from Kevin (OP): Because this is an open project, if you climb it first, you obviously get to name it. That being said, I've been working on this thing for two years and couldn't help coming up with a name in that time. So I'd like to propose "Praying to Dead Gods." I'd be stoked if you'd like to go with that too.



Pretty much the entire main wall at trail level.

Several pads and/or a spotter to move pads. It's a long one, and there are rocks to pad up at the base of the taller section. However, until you start to top out, the fall is very short, so even slider pads are probably fine for the lower section.

Start with left hand on a deep crimper and right hand in a pocket, right foot on an edge below the large block and left foot smearing on a little bulge. Traverse across to your right and top out to the left of the big crack, at the same place as Straight, No Chaser,



Starting near the left end of the slab with the Santa, Baby! crack, toward the left of the field, on the lower tier (trail level).

Clean fall.

Start in a squat facing to your left, with your left hand side-pulling on a small block, right hand in the big opening on the rail, both feet pressing below the larger block. Use the holds to the left of Straight, No Chaser.



Just to the left of Straight, No Chaser, slightly right of the midpoint of the slab.

Clean fall.

Squeeze chimney! 

There are good hand- and footholds once you’re inside the crack, so it doesn’t have to be done with pure squeeze chimney technique. But if you hate yourself want to give yourself the extra challenge, the option’s there.



Continue just a few feet down the trail from the main wall until you see the big, obvious crack.

Difficult to pad up. You might get wedged inside a ragged crack if you fall.

A very short problem with minimal footwork but good handwork. 

Start with your left hand on the big side-pull, right hand on the small edge (good for 2-3 fingers), right foot jammed into the crack and left foot floating. There's a much bigger edge just below where your right hand starts, but it's bound to shear off from a good hard pull, so avoid that one.

Work your way straight up, using the ledge above your right hand, a deep crimp right above you, the smaller ledge out to your left, and a slopey ledge to your right. There are a few other holds available if they work better for your beta.



About the midpoint of the main wall at trail level, just to the right of the taller section of the wall.

Short fall that's clean enough. Two pads recommended because there's a hump in the landing zone that's bound to make a single pad slide away from where you need it to be.

Start with left hand on small ledge, right hand on the arete; left foot on large edge and right foot smearing on the opposite side of the crack. After the start, stay to the left of the crack, going up the face.



Just to the left of Santa, Baby. Look for the big, obvious crack.

Clean fall.

A small, multi-level cliff near the Legislative Assembly (or "The Ledge" in local parlance). There's a high density of problems for such a small area, with a big range of styles and difficulty levels. Many of the problems are slightly overhanging. The problems listed are only a portion of the lines that can be climbed here.
